text.raw: By James Gallagher Health and science correspondent image copyrightOxford University/John Cairns image captionThe Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine is currently in the final stages of testing The coronavirus vaccine developed by the University of Oxford is highly effective at stopping people developing Covid 19 symptoms a large trial shows. Interim data suggests 70% protection but the researchers say the figure may be as high as 90% by tweaking the dose. The results will be seen as a triumph but come after Pfizer and Moderna vaccines showed 95% protection. However the Oxford jab is far cheaper and is easier to store and get to every corner of the world than the other two. So the vaccine will play a significant role in tackling the pandemic if it is approved for use by regulators. "The announcement today takes us another step closer to the time when we can use vaccines to bring an end to the devastation caused by the virus" said the vaccine's architect Prof Sarah Gilbert. The UK government has pre ordered 100 million doses of the Oxford vaccine and AstraZeneca says it will make three billion doses for the world next year. Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was "incredibly exciting news" and that while there were still safety checks to come "these are fantastic results". Speaking at a Downing Street briefing on Monday evening Mr Johnson added that the majority of people most in need of a vaccination in the UK might be able to get one by Easter. And Prof Andrew Pollard director of the Oxford vaccine group said it had been "a very exciting day" and paid tribute to the 20,000 volunteers in the trials around the world including more than 10,000 in the UK. media captionAstraZeneca's Mene Pangalos says Covid vaccine is 'clearly effective' What did the trial show? The vaccine has been developed in around 10 months a process that normally takes a decade. There are two results from the trial of more than 20,000 volunteers in the UK and Brazil. Overall there were 30 cases of Covid in people who had two doses of the vaccine and 101 cases in people who received a dummy injection. The researchers said it worked out at 70% protection which is better than the seasonal flu jab. Nobody getting the actual vaccine developed severe Covid or needed hospital treatment. Prof Andrew Pollard the trial's lead investigator said he was "really pleased" with the results as "it means we have a vaccine for the world". However protection was 90% in an analysis of around 3,000 people on the trial who were given a half sized first dose and a full sized second dose. Prof Pollard said the finding was "intriguing" and would mean "we would have a lot more doses to distribute." The analysis also suggested there was a reduction in the number of people being infected without developing symptoms who are still thought to be able to spread the virus. media captionLaura Foster explains why the Oxford vaccine matters When will I get a vaccine? In the UK there are four million doses of the Oxford vaccine ready to go. But nothing can happen until the vaccine has been approved by regulators who will assess the vaccine's safety effectiveness and that it is manufactured to high standard. This process will happen in the coming weeks. It is also unclear who will get this vaccine or the other vaccines the government has ordered. However the UK is preparing to press the go button on an unprecedented mass immunisation campaign that dwarfs either the annual flu or childhood vaccination programmes. Care home residents and staff will be first in the queue followed by healthcare workers and the over 80s. The plan is to then to work down through the age groups. How does it work? It uses a completely different approach to the vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna which inject part of the virus's genetic code into patients. The Oxford vaccine is a genetically modified common cold virus that used to infect chimpanzees. It has been altered to stop it causing an infection in people and to carry the blueprints for part of the coronavirus known as the spike protein. Once these blueprints are inside the body they start producing the coronavirus' spike protein which the immune system recognizes as a threat and tries to squash it. When the immune system comes into contact with the virus for real it will know what to do. Why is the low dose better? There is not a straightforward answer. One idea is the immune system rejects the vaccine which is built around a common cold virus if it is given in too big an initial dose. Or a low then high shot may be a better mimic of a coronavirus infection and lead to a better immune response. Are the results disappointing? After Pfizer and Moderna both produced vaccines delivering 95% protection from Covid 19 a figure of 70% is still highly effective but will be seen by some as relatively disappointing. But this is still a vaccine that can save lives from Covid 19 and is more effective than a seasonal flu jab. It also has crucial advantages that make it easier to use. It can be stored at fridge temperature which means it can be distributed to every corner of the world unlike the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines which need to be stored at much colder temperatures. The Oxford vaccine at a price of around £3 also costs far less than Pfizer's (around £15) or Moderna's (£25) vaccines. And the Oxford technology is more established so the vaccine is easier to mass produce cheaply. AstraZeneca has also made a "no profit pledge". image captionElisa Granato was one of the volunteers given the Oxford vaccine What difference will this make to my life? A vaccine is what we've spent the year waiting for and what lockdowns have bought time for. However producing enough vaccine and then immunising tens of millions of people in the UK and billions around the world is still a gargantuan challenge. Life will not return to normal tomorrow but the situation could improve dramatically as those most at risk are protected. Health Secretary Matt Hancock told BBC Breakfast we would be "something closer to normal" by the summer but "until we can get that vaccine rolled out we all need to look after each other". What's the reaction been? Prof Peter Horby from the University of Oxford but not involved in the trial said "This is very welcome news we can clearly see the end of tunnel now. There were no Covid hospitalisations or deaths in people who got the Oxford vaccine." Dr Stephen Griffin from the University of Leeds said "This is yet more excellent news and should be considered tremendously exciting. It has great potential to be delivered across the globe achieving huge public health benefits. England's chief medical officer Prof Chris Whitty expressed an "absolutely massive thank you" to people up and down the country who are volunteering for studies into Covid 19. "Because as we've repeatedly said it's only science that is going to get us out of this hole" he said adding that "it will be a long haul". What questions do you have about the Oxford University vaccine? In some cases your question will be published displaying your name age and location as you provide it unless you state otherwise. Your contact details will never be published. Please ensure you have read ourterms & conditionsandprivacy policy. Use this form to ask your question If you are reading this page and can't see the form you will need to visit the mobile version of the BBC website to submit your question or send them via email to YourQuestions@bbc.co.uk. Please include your name age and location with any question you send in.
text.formatted:
COVID-19: OXFORD UNIVERSITY VACCINE IS HIGHLY EFFECTIVE

  By James Gallagher 
Health and science correspondent 

image copyrightOxford University/John Cairns

image captionThe Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine is currently in the final stages of testing The
coronavirus vaccine developed by the University of Oxford is highly effective at stopping people
developing Covid-19 symptoms, a large trial shows.

Interim data suggests 70% protection, but the researchers say the figure may be as high as 90% by
tweaking the dose.

The results will be seen as a triumph, but come after Pfizer and Moderna vaccines showed 95%
protection.

However, the Oxford jab is far cheaper, and is easier to store and get to every corner of the world
than the other two.

So the vaccine will play a significant role in tackling the pandemic, if it is approved for use by
regulators.

"The announcement today takes us another step closer to the time when we can use vaccines to bring
an end to the devastation caused by [the virus]," said the vaccine's architect, Prof Sarah Gilbert.

The UK government has pre-ordered 100 million doses of the Oxford vaccine, and AstraZeneca says it
will make three billion doses for the world next year.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was "incredibly exciting news" and that while there were still
safety checks to come, "these are fantastic results".

Speaking at a Downing Street briefing on Monday evening, Mr Johnson added that the majority of
people most in need of a vaccination in the UK might be able to get one by Easter.

And Prof Andrew Pollard - director of the Oxford vaccine group - said it had been "a very exciting
day" and paid tribute to the 20,000 volunteers in the trials around the world, including more than
10,000 in the UK.

media captionAstraZeneca's Mene Pangalos says Covid vaccine is 'clearly effective' WHAT DID THE
TRIAL SHOW?
The vaccine has been developed in around 10 months, a process that normally takes a decade.

There are two results from the trial of more than 20,000 volunteers in the UK and Brazil.

Overall, there were 30 cases of Covid in people who had two doses of the vaccine and 101 cases in
people who received a dummy injection. The researchers said it worked out at 70% protection, which
is better than the seasonal flu jab.

Nobody getting the actual vaccine developed severe-Covid or needed hospital treatment.

Prof Andrew Pollard, the trial's lead investigator, said he was "really pleased" with the results as
"it means we have a vaccine for the world".

However, protection was 90% in an analysis of around 3,000 people on the trial who were given a
half-sized first dose and a full-sized second dose.

Prof Pollard said the finding was "intriguing" and would mean "we would have a lot more doses to
distribute."

The analysis also suggested there was a reduction in the number of people being infected without
developing symptoms, who are still thought to be able to spread the virus.

media captionLaura Foster explains why the Oxford vaccine matters WHEN WILL I GET A VACCINE?
In the UK there are four million doses of the Oxford vaccine ready to go. But nothing can happen
until the vaccine has been approved by regulators who will assess the vaccine's safety,
effectiveness, and that it is manufactured to high standard. This process will happen in the coming
weeks.

It is also unclear who will get this vaccine or the other vaccines the government has ordered.

However, the UK is preparing to press the go button on an unprecedented mass immunisation campaign
that dwarfs either the annual flu or childhood vaccination programmes.

Care home residents and staff will be first in the queue, followed by healthcare workers and the
over-80s. The plan is to then to work down through the age groups.

HOW DOES IT WORK?
It uses a completely different approach to the vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, which inject part
of the virus's genetic code into patients.

The Oxford vaccine is a genetically modified common cold virus that used to infect chimpanzees.

It has been altered to stop it causing an infection in people and to carry the blueprints for part
of the coronavirus, known as the spike protein.

Once these blueprints are inside the body they start producing the coronavirus' spike protein, which
the immune system recognizes as a threat and tries to squash it.

When the immune system comes into contact with the virus for real, it will know what to do.

WHY IS THE LOW DOSE BETTER?
There is not a straightforward answer.

One idea is the immune system rejects the vaccine, which is built around a common cold virus, if it
is given in too big an initial dose.

Or a low then high shot may be a better mimic of a coronavirus infection and lead to a better immune
response.

ARE THE RESULTS DISAPPOINTING?
After Pfizer and Moderna both produced vaccines delivering 95% protection from Covid-19, a figure of
70% is still highly effective, but will be seen by some as relatively disappointing.

But this is still a vaccine that can save lives from Covid-19 and is more effective than a seasonal
flu jab.

It also has crucial advantages that make it easier to use. It can be stored at fridge temperature,
which means it can be distributed to every corner of the world, unlike the Pfizer/BioNTech and
Moderna vaccines, which need to be stored at much colder temperatures.

The Oxford vaccine, at a price of around £3, also costs far less than Pfizer's (around £15) or
Moderna's (£25) vaccines.

And the Oxford technology is more established, so the vaccine is easier to mass produce cheaply.
AstraZeneca has also made a "no-profit pledge".

image captionElisa Granato was one of the volunteers given the Oxford vaccine WHAT DIFFERENCE WILL
THIS MAKE TO MY LIFE?
A vaccine is what we've spent the year waiting for and what lockdowns have bought time for.

However, producing enough vaccine and then immunising tens of millions of people in the UK, and
billions around the world, is still a gargantuan challenge.

Life will not return to normal tomorrow, but the situation could improve dramatically as those most
at risk are protected.

Health Secretary Matt Hancock told BBC Breakfast we would be "something closer to normal" by the
summer but "until we can get that vaccine rolled out, we all need to look after each other".

WHAT'S THE REACTION BEEN?
Prof Peter Horby, from the University of Oxford but not involved in the trial, said: "This is very
welcome news, we can clearly see the end of tunnel now. There were no Covid hospitalisations or
deaths in people who got the Oxford vaccine."

Dr Stephen Griffin, from the University of Leeds, said: "This is yet more excellent news and should
be considered tremendously exciting. It has great potential to be delivered across the globe,
achieving huge public health benefits.

England's chief medical officer, Prof Chris Whitty, expressed an "absolutely massive thank you" to
people up and down the country who are volunteering for studies into Covid-19.

"Because as we've repeatedly said, it's only science that is going to get us out of this hole," he
said, adding that "it will be a long haul".

What questions do you have about the Oxford University vaccine?

In some cases your question will be published, displaying your name, age and location as you provide
it, unless you state otherwise. Your contact details will never be published. Please ensure you have
read ourterms & conditionsandprivacy policy.

Use this form to ask your question:

If you are reading this page and can't see the form you will need to visit the mobile version of the 
BBC website to submit your question or send them via email to YourQuestions@bbc.co.uk. Please
include your name, age and location with any question you send in.

is-on-https.title: Uses HTTPS
is-on-https.description: All sites should be protected with HTTPS, even ones that don't handle sensitive data. This includes avoiding [mixed content](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/security/prevent-mixed-content/what-is-mixed-content), where some resources are loaded over HTTP despite the initial request being servedover HTTPS. HTTPS prevents intruders from tampering with or passively listening in on the communications between your app and your users, and is a prerequisite for HTTP/2 and many new web platform APIs. [Learn more](https://web.dev/is-on-https/).
is-on-https.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

redirects-http.title: Redirects HTTP traffic to HTTPS
redirects-http.description: If you've already set up HTTPS, make sure that you redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS in order to enable secure web features for all your users. [Learn more](https://web.dev/redirects-http/).
redirects-http.errorMessage: Required HTTPRedirect gatherer did not run.

service-worker.title: Registers a service worker that controls page and `start_url`
service-worker.description: The service worker is the technology that enables your app to use many Progressive Web App features, such as offline, add to homescreen, and push notifications. [Learn more](https://web.dev/service-worker/).
service-worker.errorMessage: Required ServiceWorker gatherer did not run.

works-offline.title: Current page responds with a 200 when offline
works-offline.description: If you're building a Progressive Web App, consider using a service worker so that your app can work offline. [Learn more](https://web.dev/works-offline/).
works-offline.errorMessage: Required Offline gatherer did not run.

viewport.title: Has a `<meta name="viewport">` tag with `width` or `initial-scale`
viewport.description: Add a `<meta name="viewport">` tag to optimize your app for mobile screens. [Learn more](https://web.dev/viewport/).
viewport.errorMessage: Required MetaElements gatherer did not run.

without-javascript.title: Contains some content when JavaScript is not available
without-javascript.description: Your app should display some content when JavaScript is disabled, even if it's just a warning to the user that JavaScript is required to use the app. [Learn more](https://web.dev/without-javascript/).
without-javascript.errorMessage: Required HTMLWithoutJavaScript gatherer did not run.

first-contentful-paint.title: First Contentful Paint
first-contentful-paint.description: First Contentful Paint marks the time at which the first text or image is painted. [Learn more](https://web.dev/first-contentful-paint/).
first-contentful-paint.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

largest-contentful-paint.title: Largest Contentful Paint
largest-contentful-paint.description: Largest Contentful Paint marks the time at which the largest text or image is painted. [Learn More](https://web.dev/lighthouse-largest-contentful-paint/)

first-meaningful-paint.title: First Meaningful Paint
first-meaningful-paint.description: First Meaningful Paint measures when the primary content of a page is visible. [Learn more](https://web.dev/first-meaningful-paint/).

load-fast-enough-for-pwa.title: Page load is fast enough on mobile networks
load-fast-enough-for-pwa.description: A fast page load over a cellular network ensures a good mobile user experience. [Learn more](https://web.dev/load-fast-enough-for-pwa/).
load-fast-enough-for-pwa.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

speed-index.title: Speed Index
speed-index.description: Speed Index shows how quickly the contents of a page are visibly populated. [Learn more](https://web.dev/speed-index/).
speed-index.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

screenshot-thumbnails.title: Screenshot Thumbnails
screenshot-thumbnails.description: This is what the load of your site looked like.
screenshot-thumbnails.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

final-screenshot.title: Final Screenshot
final-screenshot.description: The last screenshot captured of the pageload.
final-screenshot.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

estimated-input-latency.title: Estimated Input Latency
estimated-input-latency.description: Estimated Input Latency is an estimate of how long your app takes to respond to user input, in milliseconds, during the busiest 5s window of page load. If your latency is higher than 50 ms, users may perceive your app as laggy. [Learn more](https://web.dev/estimated-input-latency/).
estimated-input-latency.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

total-blocking-time.title: Total Blocking Time
total-blocking-time.description: Sum of all time periods between FCP and Time to Interactive, when task length exceeded 50ms, expressed in milliseconds. [Learn more](https://web.dev/lighthouse-total-blocking-time/).
total-blocking-time.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

max-potential-fid.title: Max Potential First Input Delay
max-potential-fid.description: The maximum potential First Input Delay that your users could experience is the duration of the longest task. [Learn more](https://web.dev/lighthouse-max-potential-fid/).
max-potential-fid.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

cumulative-layout-shift.title: Cumulative Layout Shift
cumulative-layout-shift.description: Cumulative Layout Shift measures the movement of visible elements within the viewport. [Learn more](https://web.dev/cls/).

errors-in-console.title: No browser errors logged to the console
errors-in-console.description: Errors logged to the console indicate unresolved problems. They can come from network request failures and other browser concerns. [Learn more](https://web.dev/errors-in-console/)

server-response-time.title: Initial server response time was short
server-response-time.description: Keep the server response time for the main document short because all other requests depend on it. [Learn more](https://web.dev/time-to-first-byte/).

first-cpu-idle.title: First CPU Idle
first-cpu-idle.description: First CPU Idle marks the first time at which the page's main thread is quiet enough to handle input.  [Learn more](https://web.dev/first-cpu-idle/).
first-cpu-idle.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

interactive.title: Time to Interactive
interactive.description: Time to interactive is the amount of time it takes for the page to become fully interactive. [Learn more](https://web.dev/interactive/).
interactive.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

user-timings.title: User Timing marks and measures
user-timings.description: Consider instrumenting your app with the User Timing API to measure your app's real-world performance during key user experiences. [Learn more](https://web.dev/user-timings/).
user-timings.errorMessage: Required traces gatherer did not run.

critical-request-chains.title: Avoid chaining critical requests
critical-request-chains.description: The Critical Request Chains below show you what resources are loaded with a high priority. Consider reducing the length of chains, reducing the download size of resources, or deferring the download of unnecessary resources to improve page load. [Learn more](https://web.dev/critical-request-chains/).

redirects.title: Avoid multiple page redirects
redirects.description: Redirects introduce additional delays before the page can be loaded. [Learn more](https://web.dev/redirects/).
redirects.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

installable-manifest.title: Web app manifest does not meet the installability requirements
installable-manifest.description: Browsers can proactively prompt users to add your app to their homescreen, which can lead to higher engagement. [Learn more](https://web.dev/installable-manifest/).

apple-touch-icon.title: Provides a valid `apple-touch-icon`
apple-touch-icon.description: For ideal appearance on iOS when users add a progressive web app to the home screen, define an `apple-touch-icon`. It must point to a non-transparent 192px (or 180px) square PNG. [Learn More](https://web.dev/apple-touch-icon/).

uses-text-compression.title: Enable text compression
uses-text-compression.description: Text-based resources should be served with compression (gzip, deflate or brotli) to minimize total network bytes. [Learn more](https://web.dev/uses-text-compression/).
uses-text-compression.errorMessage: Required ResponseCompression gatherer did not run.

uses-responsive-images.title: Properly size images
uses-responsive-images.description: Serve images that are appropriately-sized to save cellular data and improve load time. [Learn more](https://web.dev/uses-responsive-images/).
uses-responsive-images.errorMessage: Required ImageElements gatherer did not run.

efficient-animated-content.title: Use video formats for animated content
efficient-animated-content.description: Large GIFs are inefficient for delivering animated content. Consider using MPEG4/WebM videos for animations and PNG/WebP for static images instead of GIF to save network bytes. [Learn more](https://web.dev/efficient-animated-content/)
efficient-animated-content.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

duplicated-javascript.title: Remove duplicate modules in JavaScript bundles
duplicated-javascript.description: Remove large, duplicate JavaScript modules from bundles to reduce unnecessary bytes consumed by network activity.
duplicated-javascript.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

legacy-javascript.title: Avoid serving legacy JavaScript to modern browsers
legacy-javascript.description: Polyfills and transforms enable legacy browsers to use new JavaScript features. However, many aren't necessary for modern browsers. For your bundled JavaScript, adopt a modern script deployment strategy using module/nomodule feature detection to reduce the amount of code shipped to modern browsers, while retaining support for legacy browsers. [Learn More](https://philipwalton.com/articles/deploying-es2015-code-in-production-today/)
legacy-javascript.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

appcache-manifest.title: Avoids Application Cache
appcache-manifest.errorMessage: Required AppCacheManifest gatherer did not run.

doctype.title: Page has the HTML doctype
doctype.description: Specifying a doctype prevents the browser from switching to quirks-mode. [Learn more](https://web.dev/doctype/).
doctype.errorMessage: Required Doctype gatherer did not run.

charset.title: Properly defines charset
charset.description: A character encoding declaration is required. It can be done with a <meta> tag in the first 1024 bytes of the HTML or in the Content-Type HTTP response header. [Learn more](https://web.dev/charset/).
charset.errorMessage: Required MainDocumentContent gatherer did not run.

dom-size.title: Avoids an excessive DOM size
dom-size.description: A large DOM will increase memory usage, cause longer [style calculations](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/performance/rendering/reduce-the-scope-and-complexity-of-style-calculations), and produce costly [layout reflows](https://developers.google.com/speed/articles/reflow). [Learn more](https://web.dev/dom-size/).
dom-size.errorMessage: Required DOMStats gatherer did not run.

external-anchors-use-rel-noopener.title: Links to cross-origin destinations are safe
external-anchors-use-rel-noopener.description: Add `rel="noopener"` or `rel="noreferrer"` to any external links to improve performance and prevent security vulnerabilities. [Learn more](https://web.dev/external-anchors-use-rel-noopener/).
external-anchors-use-rel-noopener.errorMessage: Required AnchorElements gatherer did not run.

geolocation-on-start.title: Avoids requesting the geolocation permission on page load
geolocation-on-start.description: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request their location without context. Consider tying the request to a user action instead. [Learn more](https://web.dev/geolocation-on-start/).
geolocation-on-start.errorMessage: Required ConsoleMessages gatherer did not run.

no-document-write.title: Avoids `document.write()`
no-document-write.description: For users on slow connections, external scripts dynamically injected via `document.write()` can delay page load by tens of seconds. [Learn more](https://web.dev/no-document-write/).
no-document-write.errorMessage: Required ConsoleMessages gatherer did not run.

no-vulnerable-libraries.title: Avoids front-end JavaScript libraries with known security vulnerabilities
no-vulnerable-libraries.description: Some third-party scripts may contain known security vulnerabilities that are easily identified and exploited by attackers. [Learn more](https://web.dev/no-vulnerable-libraries/).

js-libraries.title: Detected JavaScript libraries
js-libraries.description: All front-end JavaScript libraries detected on the page. [Learn more](https://web.dev/js-libraries/).

notification-on-start.title: Avoids requesting the notification permission on page load
notification-on-start.description: Users are mistrustful of or confused by sites that request to send notifications without context. Consider tying the request to user gestures instead. [Learn more](https://web.dev/notification-on-start/).
notification-on-start.errorMessage: Required ConsoleMessages gatherer did not run.

password-inputs-can-be-pasted-into.title: Allows users to paste into password fields
password-inputs-can-be-pasted-into.description: Preventing password pasting undermines good security policy. [Learn more](https://web.dev/password-inputs-can-be-pasted-into/).
password-inputs-can-be-pasted-into.errorMessage: Required PasswordInputsWithPreventedPaste gatherer did not run.

uses-http2.title: Use HTTP/2
uses-http2.description: HTTP/2 offers many benefits over HTTP/1.1, including binary headers, multiplexing, and server push. [Learn more](https://web.dev/uses-http2/).
uses-http2.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

uses-passive-event-listeners.title: Uses passive listeners to improve scrolling performance
uses-passive-event-listeners.description: Consider marking your touch and wheel event listeners as `passive` to improve your page's scroll performance. [Learn more](https://web.dev/uses-passive-event-listeners/).
uses-passive-event-listeners.errorMessage: Required ConsoleMessages gatherer did not run.

meta-description.title: Document has a meta description
meta-description.description: Meta descriptions may be included in search results to concisely summarize page content. [Learn more](https://web.dev/meta-description/).
meta-description.errorMessage: Required MetaElements gatherer did not run.

http-status-code.title: Page has successful HTTP status code
http-status-code.description: Pages with unsuccessful HTTP status codes may not be indexed properly. [Learn more](https://web.dev/http-status-code/).
http-status-code.errorMessage: Required devtoolsLogs gatherer did not run.

font-size.title: Document uses legible font sizes
font-size.description: Font sizes less than 12px are too small to be legible and require mobile visitors to “pinch to zoom” in order to read. Strive to have >60% of page text ≥12px. [Learn more](https://web.dev/font-size/).
font-size.errorMessage: Required FontSize gatherer did not run.

link-text.title: Links have descriptive text
link-text.description: Descriptive link text helps search engines understand your content. [Learn more](https://web.dev/link-text/).
link-text.errorMessage: Required AnchorElements gatherer did not run.

crawlable-anchors.title: Links are crawlable
crawlable-anchors.description: Search engines may use `href` attributes on links to crawl websites. Ensure that the `href` attribute of anchor elements links to an appropriate destination, so more pages of the site can be discovered. [Learn More](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/9112205)
crawlable-anchors.errorMessage: Required AnchorElements gatherer did not run.

is-crawlable.title: Page isn’t blocked from indexing
is-crawlable.description: Search engines are unable to include your pages in search results if they don't have permission to crawl them. [Learn more](https://web.dev/is-crawable/).
is-crawlable.errorMessage: Required MetaElements gatherer did not run.

robots-txt.title: robots.txt is valid
robots-txt.description: If your robots.txt file is malformed, crawlers may not be able to understand how you want your website to be crawled or indexed. [Learn more](https://web.dev/robots-txt/).
robots-txt.errorMessage: Required RobotsTxt gatherer did not run.

tap-targets.title: Tap targets are sized appropriately
tap-targets.description: Interactive elements like buttons and links should be large enough (48x48px), and have enough space around them, to be easy enough to tap without overlapping onto other elements. [Learn more](https://web.dev/tap-targets/).
tap-targets.errorMessage: Required MetaElements gatherer did not run.

hreflang.title: Document has a valid `hreflang`
hreflang.description: hreflang links tell search engines what version of a page they should list in search results for a given language or region. [Learn more](https://web.dev/hreflang/).
hreflang.errorMessage: Required LinkElements gatherer did not run.

plugins.title: Document avoids plugins
plugins.description: Search engines can't index plugin content, and many devices restrict plugins or don't support them. [Learn more](https://web.dev/plugins/).
plugins.errorMessage: Required EmbeddedContent gatherer did not run.

canonical.title: Document has a valid `rel=canonical`
canonical.description: Canonical links suggest which URL to show in search results. [Learn more](https://web.dev/canonical/).
canonical.errorMessage: Required LinkElements gatherer did not run.

structured-data.title: Structured data is valid
structured-data.description: Run the [Structured Data Testing Tool](https://search.google.com/structured-data/testing-tool/) and the [Structured Data Linter](http://linter.structured-data.org/) to validate structured data. [Learn more](https://web.dev/structured-data/).

accessibility.title: Accessibility
accessibility.description: These checks highlight opportunities to [improve the accessibility of your web app](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility). Only a subset of accessibility issues can be automatically detected so manual testing is also encouraged.
accessibility.manualDescription: These items address areas which an automated testing tool cannot cover. Learn more in our guide on [conducting an accessibility review](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/accessibility/how-to-review).

seo.title: SEO
seo.description: These checks ensure that your page is optimized for search engine results ranking. There are additional factors Lighthouse does not check that may affect your search ranking. [Learn more](https://support.google.com/webmasters/answer/35769).
seo.manualDescription: Run these additional validators on your site to check additional SEO best practices.

pwa.title: Progressive Web App
pwa.description: These checks validate the aspects of a Progressive Web App. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist).
pwa.manualDescription: These checks are required by the baseline [PWA Checklist](https://developers.google.com/web/progressive-web-apps/checklist) but are not automatically checked by Lighthouse. They do not affect your score but it's important that you verify them manually.

load-opportunities.title: Opportunities
load-opportunities.description: These suggestions can help your page load faster. They don't [directly affect](https://web.dev/performance-scoring/) the Performance score.

budgets.title: Budgets
budgets.description: Performance budgets set standards for the performance of your site.

diagnostics.title: Diagnostics
diagnostics.description: More information about the performance of your application. These numbers don't [directly affect](https://web.dev/performance-scoring/) the Performance score.

a11y-best-practices.title: Best practices
a11y-best-practices.description: These items highlight common accessibility best practices.

a11y-color-contrast.title: Contrast
a11y-color-contrast.description: These are opportunities to improve the legibility of your content.

a11y-names-labels.title: Names and labels
a11y-names-labels.description: These are opportunities to improve the semantics of the controls in your application. This may enhance the experience for users of assistive technology, like a screen reader.

a11y-navigation.title: Navigation
a11y-navigation.description: These are opportunities to improve keyboard navigation in your application.

a11y-aria.title: ARIA
a11y-aria.description: These are opportunities to improve the usage of ARIA in your application which may enhance the experience for users of assistive technology, like a screen reader.

a11y-language.title: Internationalization and localization
a11y-language.description: These are opportunities to improve the interpretation of your content by users in different locales.

a11y-audio-video.title: Audio and video
a11y-audio-video.description: These are opportunities to provide alternative content for audio and video. This may improve the experience for users with hearing or vision impairments.

a11y-tables-lists.title: Tables and lists
a11y-tables-lists.description: These are opportunities to improve the experience of reading tabular or list data using assistive technology, like a screen reader.

seo-mobile.title: Mobile Friendly
seo-mobile.description: Make sure your pages are mobile friendly so users don’t have to pinch or zoom in order to read the content pages. [Learn more](https://developers.google.com/search/mobile-sites/).

seo-content.title: Content Best Practices
seo-content.description: Format your HTML in a way that enables crawlers to better understand your app’s content.

seo-crawl.title: Crawling and Indexing
seo-crawl.description: To appear in search results, crawlers need access to your app.

rendererFormattedStrings.lsPerformanceCategoryDescription: [Lighthouse](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse/) analysis of the current page on an emulated mobile network. Values are estimated and may vary.
rendererFormattedStrings.toplevelWarningsMessage: There were issues affecting this run of Lighthouse:
rendererFormattedStrings.varianceDisclaimer: Values are estimated and may vary. The [performance score is calculated](https://web.dev/performance-scoring/) directly from these metrics.

(function() {
  var check = document.createElement('script');
  if (!('noModule' in check) && 'onbeforeload' in check) {
    var support = false;
    document.addEventListener('beforeload', function(e) {
      if (e.target === check) {
        support = true;
      } else if (!e.target.hasAttribute('nomodule') || !support) {
        return;
      }
      e.preventDefault();
    }, true);

    check.type = 'module';
    check.src = '.';
    document.head.appendChild(check);
    check.remove();
  }
}());

class="css-1pl2zfy-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">Covid-19: Oxford University vaccine is highly effective</h1><p class="css-1pjc44v-Contributor e5xb54n0"><span><strong>By James Gallagher</strong><br>Health and science correspondent</span></p><div><dl class="css-1c3ha30-MetadataStrip e1ojgjhb0"><div class="css-8d0yke-MetadataStripItem e1ojgjhb1"><dt class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden ed0g1kj0"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">Related Topics</span><div class="css-1emjddl-Cluster e1ihwmse0"><ul class="css-1oubwgi-ClusterItems e1ihwmse1"><li><a href="/news/topics/cyz0z8w0ydwt" class="css-1881xj2-StyledLink ed0g1kj1">Coronavirus pandemic</a></li></ul></div></div></div></header><div data-component="image-block" class="css-vk3nhx-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><span class="css-1hq4gmv-Placeholder e16icw910"><span><img alt="Laboratory scientist / technician handling blood samples from coronavirus vaccine trials inside Oxford University's Jenner Institute on June 25, 2020" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/240/cpsprodpb/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg 624w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/800/cpsprodpb/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg 976w" src="https://c.files.bbci.co.uk/10658/production/_115606176_hi062612825.jpg" width="976" height="549" loading="lazy" class="css-evoj7m-Image ee0ct7c0"><noscript></noscript></span></span><span class="css-1ecljvk-StyledFigureCopyright e34k3c23"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">image copyright</span>Oxford University/John Cairns</span></div><figcaption class="css-1rnnz6t-StyledFigureCaption e34k3c21"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">image caption</span>The Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine is currently in the final stages of testing</figcaption></figure></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p><b class="css-14iz86j-BoldText e5tfeyi0">The coronavirus vaccine developed by the University of Oxford is highly effective at stopping people developing Covid-19 symptoms, a large trial shows. </b></p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Interim data suggests 70% protection, but the researchers say the figure may be as high as 90% by tweaking the dose. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>The results will be seen as a triumph, but come after Pfizer and Moderna vaccines showed 95% protection.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>However, the Oxford jab is far cheaper, and is easier to store and get to every corner of the world than the other two. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>So the vaccine will play a significant role in tackling the pandemic, if it is approved for use by regulators. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>"The announcement today takes us another step closer to the time when we can use vaccines to bring an end to the devastation caused by [the virus]," said the vaccine's architect, Prof Sarah Gilbert.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>The UK government has pre-ordered 100 million doses of the Oxford vaccine, and AstraZeneca says it will make three billion doses for the world next year. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was "incredibly exciting news" and that while there were still safety checks to come, "these are fantastic results".</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Speaking at a Downing Street briefing on Monday evening, Mr Johnson added that the majority of people most in need of a vaccination in the UK might be able to get one by Easter.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>And Prof Andrew Pollard - director of the Oxford vaccine group - said it had been "a very exciting day" and paid tribute to the 20,000 volunteers in the trials around the world, including more than 10,000 in the UK.</p></div></div><div data-component="media-block" class="css-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><div class="css-1uy4vn0-Container e1h75hkw0" id="bbcMediaPlayer0"><div style="position:relative;z-index:999;height:100%;width:100%;padding-bottom:56.25%" id="smphtml5iframebbcMediaPlayer0wrp"><iframe id="smphtml5iframebbcMediaPlayer0" name="smphtml5iframebbcMediaPlayer0" allow="autoplay" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" lang="en-GB" allowfullscreen="" allowtransparency="" style="position:absolute;left:0;top:0;width:100%;height:100%" src="//emp.bbc.co.uk/emp/SMPj/2.36.7/iframe.html" title="AstraZeneca executive: 'The vaccine is clearly effective'"></iframe></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1rnnz6t-StyledFigureCaption e34k3c21"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">media caption</span>AstraZeneca's Mene Pangalos says Covid vaccine is 'clearly effective'</figcaption></figure></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">What did the trial show?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>The vaccine has been developed in around 10 months, a process that normally takes a decade.</p></div></div><div data-component="unordered-list-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><div class="css-1pzprxn-BulletListContainer e5tfeyi3"><ul role="list"><li><a href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-55041371" class="css-yidnqd-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">Oxford vaccine: How did they make it so quickly?</a></li></ul></div></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>There are two results from the trial of more than 20,000 volunteers in the UK and Brazil.  </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Overall, there were 30 cases of Covid in people who had two doses of the vaccine and 101 cases in people who received a dummy injection. The researchers said it worked out at 70% protection, which is better than the seasonal flu jab.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Nobody getting the actual vaccine developed severe-Covid or needed hospital treatment.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Prof Andrew Pollard, the trial's lead investigator, said he was "really pleased" with the results as "it means we have a vaccine for the world".</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>However, protection was 90% in an analysis of around 3,000 people on the trial who were given a half-sized first dose and a full-sized second dose. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Prof Pollard said the finding was "intriguing" and would mean "we would have a lot more doses to distribute."</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>The analysis also suggested there was a reduction in the number of people being infected without developing symptoms, who are still thought to be able to spread the virus. </p></div></div><div data-component="media-block" class="css-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><div class="css-1uy4vn0-Container e1h75hkw0" id="bbcMediaPlayer1"><div data-testid="bbc-logo-wrapper" class="css-1d84lqw-LogoIconWrapper e1h75hkw2"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" 00-7.39-1.28 19.92 19.92 0 00-9 1.7 15.8 15.8 0 00-6.57 5.51 14.64 14.64 0 006.46 21.71 21.75 21.75 0 009.09 1.65 26.09 26.09 0 007.1-1.2 34.81 34.81 0 008.5-4z"></path></svg></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-1rnnz6t-StyledFigureCaption e34k3c21"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">media caption</span>Laura Foster explains why the Oxford vaccine matters</figcaption></figure></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">When will I get a vaccine?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>In the UK there are four million doses of the Oxford vaccine ready to go. But nothing can happen until the vaccine has been approved by regulators who will assess the vaccine's safety, effectiveness, and that it is manufactured to high standard. This process will happen in the coming weeks. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>It is also unclear who will get this vaccine or the other vaccines the government has ordered.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>However, the UK is preparing to press the go button on an unprecedented mass immunisation campaign that dwarfs either the annual flu or childhood vaccination programmes. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Care home residents and staff will be first in the queue, followed by healthcare workers and the over-80s. The plan is to then to work down through the age groups. </p></div></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">How does it work?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>It uses a completely different approach to the vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, which inject part of the virus's genetic code into patients. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>The Oxford vaccine is a genetically modified common cold virus that used to infect chimpanzees.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>It has been altered to stop it causing an infection in people and to carry the blueprints for part of the coronavirus, known as the spike protein.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Once these blueprints are inside the body they start producing the coronavirus' spike protein, which the immune system recognizes as a threat and tries to squash it. </p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="css-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><span class="css-bdt5fk-Placeholder e16icw910"><span><img alt="How the coronavirus vaccine works: The vaccine is made from a weakened version of a common cold virus (known as an adenovirus) from chimpanzees that has been modified so it cannot grow in humans. Scientists then added genes for the spike surface protein of the coronavirus. This should prompt the immune system to produce neutralising antibodies, which would recognise and prevent any future coronavirus infection." srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/240/cpsprodpb/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png 624w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/800/cpsprodpb/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png 976w" src="https://c.files.bbci.co.uk/134D4/production/_115606097_bc573c25-9c85-4edf-89ea-f9714db33417.png" width="640" height="1191" loading="lazy" class="css-evoj7m-Image ee0ct7c0"><noscript></noscript></span></span><span class="css-1ecljvk-StyledFigureCopyright e34k3c23"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">image copyright</span>AFP</span></div></figure></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>When the immune system comes into contact with the virus for real, it will know what to do.</p></div></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">Why is the low dose better?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>There is not a straightforward answer.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>One idea is the immune system rejects the vaccine, which is built around a common cold virus, if it is given in too big an initial dose.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Or a low then high shot may be a better mimic of a coronavirus infection and lead to a better immune response. </p></div></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">Are the results disappointing?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>After Pfizer and Moderna both produced vaccines delivering 95% protection from Covid-19, a figure of 70% is still highly effective, but will be seen by some as relatively disappointing. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>But this is still a vaccine that can save lives from Covid-19 and is more effective than a seasonal flu jab. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>It also has crucial advantages that make it easier to use. It can be stored at fridge temperature, which means it can be distributed to every corner of the world, unlike the Pfizer/BioNTech and Moderna vaccines, which need to be stored at much colder temperatures. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>The Oxford vaccine, at a price of around £3, also costs far less than Pfizer's (around £15) or Moderna's (£25) vaccines. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>And the Oxford technology is more established, so the vaccine is easier to mass produce cheaply. AstraZeneca has also made a "no-profit pledge". </p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="css-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><span class="css-1xtcmof-Placeholder e16icw910"><span><img alt="Elisa Granato receiving the vaccine" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/240/cpsprodpb/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg 624w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/800/cpsprodpb/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg 976w" src="https://c.files.bbci.co.uk/21CB/production/_111915680_photo-2020-04-23-18-02-42.jpg" width="976" height="549" loading="lazy" class="css-evoj7m-Image ee0ct7c0"><noscript></noscript></span></span></div><figcaption class="css-1rnnz6t-StyledFigureCaption e34k3c21"><span class="css-oyqyoe-VisuallyHidden e1y6uwnp0">image caption</span>Elisa Granato was one of the volunteers given the Oxford vaccine</figcaption></figure></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">What difference will this make to my life?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>A vaccine is what we've spent the year waiting for and what lockdowns have bought time for. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>However, producing enough vaccine and then immunising tens of millions of people in the UK, and billions around the world, is still a gargantuan challenge. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Life will not return to normal tomorrow, but the situation could improve dramatically as those most at risk are protected. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Health Secretary Matt Hancock told BBC Breakfast we would be "something closer to normal" by the summer but "until we can get that vaccine rolled out, we all need to look after each other".</p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="css-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><span class="css-pgrlbd-Placeholder e16icw910"><span><img alt="Graphic" srcset="https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/240/cpsprodpb/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png 240w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/320/cpsprodpb/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png 320w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png 480w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png 624w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/800/cpsprodpb/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png 800w, https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/976/cpsprodpb/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png 976w" src="https://c.files.bbci.co.uk/B8DA/production/_115622374_more_vaccines_compared_v5-nc.png" width="1920" height="1659" loading="lazy" class="css-evoj7m-Image ee0ct7c0"><noscript></noscript></span></span></div></figure></div><div data-component="crosshead-block" class="css-mysbf6-ComponentWrapper-CrossheadComponentWrapper e1xue1i84"><h2 class="css-qozapo-StyledHeading e1fj1fc10">What's the reaction been?</h2></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Prof Peter Horby, from the University of Oxford but not involved in the trial, said: "This is very welcome news, we can clearly see the end of tunnel now. There were no Covid hospitalisations or deaths in people who got the Oxford vaccine."</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>Dr Stephen Griffin, from the University of Leeds, said: "This is yet more excellent news and should be considered tremendously exciting. It has great potential to be delivered across the globe, achieving huge public health benefits. </p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>England's chief medical officer, Prof Chris Whitty, expressed an "absolutely massive thank you" to people up and down the country who are volunteering for studies into Covid-19.</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p>"Because as we've repeatedly said, it's only science that is going to get us out of this hole," he said, adding that "it will be a long haul".</p></div></div><div data-component="text-block" class="css-uf6wea-RichTextComponentWrapper e1xue1i83"><div class="css-83cqas-RichTextContainer e5tfeyi2"><p><i class="css-po6dm6-ItalicText e5tfeyi1">Follow </i><i class="css-po6dm6-ItalicText e5tfeyi1">James </i><a href="https://twitter.com/JamesTGallagher" class="css-yidnqd-InlineLink e1no5rhv0">on Twitter</a>"</p></div></div><div data-component="image-block" class="css-18mjolk-ComponentWrapper e1xue1i80"><figure class="css-2y05cd-StyledFigure e34k3c20"><div class="css-kwaqyc-StyledFigureContainer e34k3c22"><span class="css-1onuslq-Placeholder ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"\"The announcement today takes us another step closer to the time when we can use vaccines to bring an end to the devastation caused by [the virus],\" said the vaccine's architect, Prof Sarah Gilbert.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"\"The announcement today takes us another step closer to the time when we can use vaccines to bring an end to the devastation caused by [the virus],\" said the vaccine's architect, Prof Sarah Gilbert.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"The UK government has pre-ordered 100 million doses of the Oxford vaccine, and AstraZeneca says it will make three billion doses for the world next year. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was \"incredibly exciting news\" and that while there were still safety checks to come, \"these are fantastic results\".","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Prime Minister Boris Johnson said it was \"incredibly exciting news\" and that while there were still safety checks to come, \"these are fantastic results\".","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Speaking at a Downing Street briefing on Monday evening, Mr Johnson added that the majority of people most in need of a vaccination in the UK might be able to get one by Easter.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Speaking at a Downing Street briefing on Monday evening, Mr Johnson added that the majority of people most in need of a vaccination in the UK might be able to get one by Easter.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"And Prof Andrew Pollard - ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"There are two results from the trial of more than 20,000 volunteers in the UK and Brazil.  ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Overall, there were 30 cases of Covid in people who had two doses of the vaccine and 101 cases in people who received a dummy injection. The researchers said it worked out at 70% protection, which is better than the seasonal flu jab.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Overall, there were 30 cases of Covid in people who had two doses of the vaccine and 101 cases in people who received a dummy injection. The researchers said it worked out at 70% protection, which is better than the seasonal flu jab.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Nobody getting the actual vaccine developed severe-Covid or needed hospital treatment.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Nobody getting the actual vaccine developed severe-Covid or needed hospital treatment.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Prof Andrew Pollard, the trial's lead investigator, said he was \"really pleased\" with the results as \"it means we have a vaccine for the world\".","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Prof Andrew Pollard, the trial's lead investigator, said he was \"really pleased\" with the results as \"it means we have a vaccine for the world\".","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"However, protection was 90% in an analysis of around 3,000 people on the trial who were given a half-sized first dose and a full-sized second dose. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"However, protection was 90% in an analysis of around 3,000 people on the trial who were given a half-sized first dose and a full-sized second dose. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Prof Pollard said the finding was \"intriguing\" and would mean \"we would have a lot more doses to distribute.\"","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Prof Pollard said the finding was \"intriguing\" and would mean \"we would have a lot more doses to distribute.\"","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"The analysis also suggested there was a reduction in the number of people being infected without developing symptoms, who are still thought to be able to spread the virus. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"The analysis also suggested there was a reduction in the number of people being infected without developing symptoms, who are still thought to be able to spread the virus. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"media","model":{"caption":"Laura Foster explains why the Oxford vaccine matters","media":{"__typename":"ElementsMediaPlayer","items":[{"id":"p0903jmb","title":"Covid 19: Why the Oxford vaccine matters","holdingImageUrl":"https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/images/ic/$recipe/p0905194.jpg","kind":"programme","isEmbeddingAllowed":true,"isAdvertisingAllowed":true}]}}},{"type":"crosshead","text":"When will I get a vaccine?"},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"In the UK there are four million doses of the Oxford vaccine ready to go. This process will happen in the coming weeks. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"It is also unclear who will get this vaccine or the other vaccines the government has ordered.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"It is also unclear who will get this vaccine or the other vaccines the government has ordered.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"However, the UK is preparing to press the go button on an unprecedented mass immunisation campaign that dwarfs either the annual flu or childhood vaccination programmes. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"However, the UK is preparing to press the go button on an unprecedented mass immunisation campaign that dwarfs either the annual flu or childhood vaccination programmes. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Care home residents and staff will be first in the queue, followed by healthcare workers and the over-80s. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"Care home residents and staff will be first in the queue, followed by healthcare workers and the over-80s. The plan is to then to work down through the age groups. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"crosshead","text":"How does it work?"},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"It uses a completely different approach to the vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, which inject part of the virus's genetic code into patients. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"It uses a completely different approach to the vaccines from Pfizer and Moderna, which inject part of the virus's genetic code into patients. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"The Oxford vaccine is a genetically modified common cold virus that used to infect chimpanzees.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"The Oxford vaccine is a genetically modified common cold virus that used to infect chimpanzees.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"It has been altered to stop it causing an infection in people and to carry the blueprints for part of the coronavirus, known as the spike protein.","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"It has been altered to stop it causing an infection in people and to carry the blueprints for part of the coronavirus, known as the spike protein.","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"Once these blueprints are inside the body they start producing the coronavirus' spike protein, which the immune system recognizes as a threat and tries to squash it. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"crosshead","text":"Are the results disappointing?"},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"After Pfizer and Moderna both produced vaccines delivering 95% protection from Covid-19, a figure of 70% is still highly effective, but will be seen by some as relatively disappointing. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"After Pfizer and Moderna both produced vaccines delivering 95% protection from Covid-19, a figure of 70% is still highly effective, but will be seen by some as relatively disappointing. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"But this is still a vaccine that can save lives from Covid-19 and is more effective than a seasonal flu jab. ","blocks":[{"type":"fragment","model":{"text":"But this is still a vaccine that can save lives from Covid-19 and is more effective than a seasonal flu jab. ","attributes":[]}}]}}]}},{"type":"text","model":{"blocks":[{"type":"paragraph","model":{"text":"It also has crucial advantages that make it easier to use.
